title.narrative: Phase IV Multi-Sector Response for the IDPs and Vulnerable Host communities in Yirol East

description.narrative: The rainfall over most of the cropping areas started late with inadequate amounts in many places up to the end of May 2017. This caused late planting of crops and may result in harvesting delays. At the national level, the further deterioration of macroeconomic conditions has forced prices (of food and non-food items) to climb above levels observed last year. Over half of the South Sudanese population needs humanitarian assistance. Conflict has driven massive displacement and is expected to continue to limit household access to natural sources of food, including fish and wild foods. The daily wage rate for casual labour currently purchases under 3 kilograms of cereal in most areas of the country and, as a result, households face extreme difficulty purchasing sufficient food to meet their basic food needs.In terms of peace, governance and access to land, most parts of Lakes state were affected, mildly, by inter-clan clashes especially in the cattle camps by fighting youth. Throughout the country, there were some incidences of looting of relief food from trucks and warehouses with nearly 670 metric tonnes of food lost in July (15 incidences) compared to 7 and 5 June and May respectively.In Rumbek, which neighbours Yirol, 77 metric tonnes of food items in 3 trucks were looted on July 3 in Mayom village.
